So-called ""honor killing"" is common in Afghanistan, along with other gruesome punishments for women suspected of contact with men outside the family.
It's even considered a dishonor when a woman is the victim of sexual assault.
Hundreds of women are in Afghan prisons for such ""moral crimes"" as being the victims of rape.
It's not clear if her brothers knew it, but Lina says one of her in-laws was regularly abusing her, physically and sexually.
Women in remote villages have little recourse, almost no route of escape.
Most spend life barely leaving the house.
But something made Lina try.
(Through translator) I was terrified to think of running away from home, but suddenly a voice from inside told me to flee before my brothers killed me.
I took one of their cloaks and wrapped it around me to look like a man.
Then I slipped out of the house and started walking to the foreigners' base nearby.
She approached the gate.
The people at the gate noticed that someone was trying to find her.
When they realized that she was in danger, they took her in.
U.S.
Marine Major Jennifer Larsen was to become Lina's almost constant companion for the next several weeks.
She said the guards at the gate saw the same car passing again and again.
Each time it drew near, Lina looked petrified.
They took her to a doctor who discovered fresh bruises on her back and knees from the beating.
(Through translator) They took me to a tent with three American women and an Afghan translator.
They treated me very well and there were no American men there.
Even that small corner of the American base was a new world for Lina, after a life of sequester in the village.
Things like television and hot running water were new, as was the existence of books, written words and even written numbers.
But Larsen says the girl embraced them.
She devoured new foods from the cafeteria, especially ice cream and Doritos.
She quickly gained a small English vocabulary, including phrases from the PG-rated movies they watched to pass the time.
Some showed men and women kissing.
Kiss was a favorite new word, says Larsen.
She was scared and she was overwhelmed, but she was a strong person.
And as she had new things come to her, she adapted quickly.
And I found out that she was very bright.
She wanted to get away from where she was.
That was her main interest.
Anytime you asked her a question, it was, do I have to go back?
And our answer at the time was no, and we needed to figure out how we could keep that promise.
It was a big promise.
Saving a teenage girl was not part of the battle plan for U.S.
forces in Afghanistan.
It might have even jeopardized that mission.
Afghan advisers told Americans at the base, very bluntly, to keep peace with the community, Lina had to go home, even if it meant her death.
Her original crime now paled in comparison to the fact that Lina had spent weeks living with non-Muslim foreigners, says Huma Safi, a women's rights advocate in Kabul.
In Afghan society, women are staying with their families.
When they spend nights other places, it's a dishonor for the families.
It's not only the military base, but in anywhere.
They don't want their daughters to spend the night somewhere else.
An elder from the community stayed on the base with Lina, but he stopped speaking to her once she said she wanted to stay with the foreigners.
Her family also tried to convince her to come home, but Lina knew it was a trick, says Major Larsen.
I met her sister, and the hard part was, as I watched her sister beg her to come home, even her niece and nephew, who were very young, were there as well.
And she did hug them and she was glad to see them but as soon as her sister even suggested that she come back home, the whole meeting came to a screeching halt.
She had no time for her sister, and she asked her to leave.
It was hard to watch.
All the other people that were there in this situation were crying.
I couldn't understand everything that was being said, but at that moment, an interpreter was unnecessary because the range of emotion and the body language said more than words could.
Lina also saw her brothers again.
They surprised her by showing up at a meeting near the base.
Major Larsen says she feared the brothers might try to kidnap Lina or even throw acid on her at the meeting.
Lina says she knew her family planned to lure her home to kill her.
(Through translator) My brothers pleaded with me to return home.
I told them no. They said they would let me marry whoever makes me happy.
I asked them, why would I ever believe you?
This is where the story in Afghanistan often ends.
The woman is sent home, and later killed by her family to cleanse the dishonor.
But Lina's tale has a different ending.

and Afghan officials helped fly her to a shelter in a larger city.
